Award.AwardTitle: Recruiting and Retaining Teacher Leaders in Physics and Chemistry

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: Kennesaw State University and the Georgia Institute of Technology, in partnership with five school districts (Cobb County School District, Gwinnett County Schools, Atlantic Public Schools, DeKalb County Schools, and Paulding County School District), and two nonprofit organizations (the American Chemical Society and MetroRESA), are collaborating to address the recruitment, preparation and retention of teachers and master teachers in the critical shortage areas of secondary physics and chemistry. The partnership's aggressive recruitment strategy includes marketing through professional engineering societies, the Georgia Tech alumni community, and the chemistry and chemical engineering network associated with the American Chemical Society. The project is recruiting one cohort of 16 Teaching Fellows from STEM professions into a one-year teacher preparation program, then supporting them during their induction and early career years with frequent and targeted mentoring and other professional development experiences. The project is also recruiting 16 current physics and chemistry teachers as Master Teaching Fellows, to prepare them for broader leadership roles at district, state, and national levels through a five-year intensive program that includes research with university STEM faculty, subject-specific pedagogical training, and participation in professional education organizations. This teacher preparation and leadership development programming is built on a foundation of educational research and theory and an existing Master of Arts in Teaching program at Kennesaw State, and is also taking advantage of a wealth of practical experience of project team members who have been K-12 teachers in diverse and challenging science classrooms. Evaluation of the project is taking place in two stages, early and later program, and is studying the impact of the recruiting strategies on the growth of the Master's program; how the Master Teaching Fellows serve as teacher leaders and how this program facilitates the Fellows' professional growth; the impact of the teacher preparation and induction support on the Teaching Fellows; and the impact of the program on the retention of all Fellows. Results from the project are being disseminated widely through web media as well as national and international professional meetings and publications.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Recruiting and Retaining Teacher Leaders in Physics and Chemistry Noyce project at Kennesaw State University aimed to address the challenges of teacher shortages and teacher turnover in the greater metro-Atlanta area of Georgia. To that end, the project recruited 32 teachers—16 pre-service teachers seeking chemistry and physics certification and 16 in-service teachers holding certification in those areas—to participate in a teacher leader development program. New teaching fellows (TFs) were recruited as career-changers with prior work or military experiences, or as recent college graduates with degrees in engineering or science. Experienced master teaching fellows (MTFs) were nominated by their schools in high-needs districts and selected by the project based on (1) their advanced degrees (Master’s or higher), (2) written perspectives on leadership and career goals, and (3) potential to lead from the classroom.

The 5-year project was explicitly organized around developing teacher leaders, who engage in leadership activities while maintaining a classroom teaching load, rather than leaders of teachers, who serve in formal or administrative roles over teachers without direct instruction of students. The project aimed to support experienced MTFs as they pursued new leadership opportunities, while advocating for retention in the classroom. Leadership from the classroom was framed around four metaphors for teacher leader development: teachers as … (1) fully functioning educators, (2) reflective practitioners, (3) learning partners and (4)  scholars. For instance, the project partnered TFs with MTFs (as mentor teachers) to develop reciprocal interactions that would support the growth of both groups, while enhancing their chemistry and physics teaching communities -- i.e., growth as learning partners. Further, both groups first participated in, then took ownership of a yearly conference in the fall where they presented and discussed best practices with regional colleagues -- i.e. operating as scholars. It was believed that these opportunities to work collaboratively, with similarly passionate individuals and have greater impact on their local educational systems would increase the professional satisfaction of both groups and support their retention in the classroom.

From its conception, the project was made possible by a network of key collaborations and partnerships that had not been established in Georgia prior to the award, and which represented a novel attempt to recruit, prepare and retain teachers. At Kennesaw State University (KSU), the three-semester long Master of Arts in Teaching (MAT) program had just been established to prepare individuals already holding baccalaureate degrees in Science, Technology, Engineering and Mathematics (STEM) subjects to become teachers. At that time, the number of candidates in the MAT program pursuing physics and chemistry teaching certification was relatively low, despite the demand for teachers in these subjects. By partnering with the Georgia Institute of Technology, which did not offer programs leading to teaching certification or education credentials, the project was able to recruit TFs from a new pool of STEM degree holders. This recruitment population included new STEM degree holders with strong content knowledge and alumni with industry-based experiences looking to change careers or rejoin the workforce after raising a family. Recruiting experienced MTFs was facilitated by partnerships with 5 metro-Atlanta school districts. Once in the program, MTFs and TFs interacted with local and national educators occupying informal and formal leadership positions, and learned about opportunities at the school, district, state and national spheres of influence. A final critical partner was the Metropolitan Regional Education Service Agency, which delivered a state recognized Teacher Leadership Endorsement program for MTFs.

        Overall, the project has moved 16 TFs and 16 MTFs through their teaching commitments of 4 and 5 years, respectively, during which time they continued to impact physics and chemistry students. Leadership opportunities have been leveraged for both student benefits and teacher career development. For example, a TF has secured funding from the Governor’s Office for engineering design student projects, and also been recognized nationally as an Allen Distinguished Educator. Similarly, an MTF has been awarded competitive funds to establish a celestial observatory on a high school campus, and been invited to speak in consecutive years at an astronomy conference in Hawaii. The project has also accelerated the trajectories of teachers toward becoming Gifted and AP certified, leading local STEM initiatives, disseminating their practices via online materials and scholarly presentations, pursuing advanced degrees, and influencing education policy.

These outcomes have informed the project’s conception of teacher leadership. An evolving model now supports concurrent, rather than sequential, development of the four teacher leader metaphors and describes activities for addressing each aspect. The model has been spread by the project through conference presentations and peer-reviewed manuscripts, but also implemented at the home institutions of project faculty. The model has had even broader impacts by engaging faculty from the fields of management and business administration in projects related to STEM education, leading to new areas of research and practice for several recently funded grants.
